body.p: In this explainer, we will learn how to define, determine, and convert between a compound’s empirical and molecular formulas.

The composition of a molecule can be expressed as a molecular formula. The molecular formula tells us the exact number of atom of each element in a molecule. For example, the molecular formula of water, \ch{H2 O}, indicates that every water molecule will contain two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom. The molecular formula of glucose, \ch{C6 H12 O6}, indicates that every glucose molecule will contain six carbon atoms, twelve hydrogen atoms, and six oxygen atoms.

sidebar.title: Definition: Molecular Formula
sidebar.p: A molecular formula is a chemical formula expressing the exact number of atom of each element in a molecule.

body.p: The ratio of carbon atoms to hydrogen atoms to oxygen atoms in a molecule of glucose is $6:12:6$. This ratio can be simplified to $1:2:1$. We can write the simplified ratio as a chemical formula, \ch{CH2 O}. This is the empirical formula of glucose. The empirical formula tells us the simplest whole number ratio of the elements in a molecule.

sidebar.title: Definition: Empirical Formula
sidebar.p: An empirical formula is a chemical formula that indicates the elements in a molecule or ionic compound and the simplest whole number ratio of atom of each element.

body.p: Empirical formulas are also used to represent the chemical formulas of ionic compounds because ionic compounds exist as a three-dimensional network of ions rather than a discrete molecular unit. The sodium chloride crystal lattice, shown below, must have equal numbers of \ch{Na^+} and \ch{Cl^-} in order for the compound to be electrically neutral. Therefore, the simplified ratio of sodium to chlorine in sodium chloride is $1:1$ and the empirical formula is \ch{NaCl}.
We can easily determine the empirical formula from the molecular formula by dividing the subscripts in the molecular formula by their greatest common factor.

example.title: Determining an Empirical Formula from a Molecular Formula

stem.p: Caffeine has the chemical formula \ch{C8 H10 N4 O2}. What is its empirical formula?

answer.p: The ratio of carbon atoms to hydrogen atoms to nitrogen atoms to oxygen atoms in the molecular formula is $8:10:4:2$. The greatest common factor of these values is 2. We can divide each value by the greatest common factor to simplify the ratio to $4:5:2:1$.
We can replace the subscripts in the molecular formula with the simplified ratio to give us the empirical formula of \ch{C4 H5 N2 O}.

body.p: It is possible for the empirical formula and molecular formula to be the same. For example, formaldehyde, a biological specimen preservative, has the molecular formula \ch{CH2 O} and the empirical formula \ch{CH2 O}. It is also possible for multiple molecules to have the same empirical formula. Glucose and formaldehyde both have an empirical formula of \ch{CH2 O}.

Empirical formulas are often derived from experimental data. In fact, the word empirical means based on observation or experience. In order to determine the empirical formula, we will need to experimentally determine the percent composition or measure the mass of each element in a pure sample. In either case, we will need to calculate the number of mole of each element in order to determine the ratio.

sidebar.title: Definition: Percent Composition
sidebar.p: Percent composition is the percent by mass of each element in a compound.

body.p: Decimal values that are close to whole numbers can be rounded to the nearest whole number. The sign $\approx$ means “approximately equal to.” Once the simplest whole number ratio has been determined, it can be written as a chemical formula. Therefore, the empirical formula of this sample is \ch{CO2}.

In this example, we knew the mass of each element in the sample. If we knew the percent composition of each element, for example, $27.3\%$ carbon and $72.7\%$ oxygen, we would begin by assuming that the sample size is 100gram. This would allow us to represent the amount of each element in gram— 27.3gram of carbon and 72.7gram of oxygen—so that we could convert it into mole and find the molar ratio.
The complete process for determining the empirical formula is shown below.

example.title: Determining an Empirical Formula from Experimental Data

stem.p: In an experiment, mercury oxide is heated in a container, producing oxygen gas and mercury in its pure elemental form. The results of the experiment are shown below. [\ch{Hg} = 201gram per mole, \ch{O} = 16 gram per mole]

tr.th: Mass of Empty Container + Mercury Oxide

ol.li: What is the mass of oxygen gas lost?
What is the mass of mercury produced?
What is the empirical formula for the compound of mercury oxide?

answer.p: As the mercury oxide is heated, the oxygen is driven off leaving behind the pure mercury metal. The difference between the mass of the container with the mercury oxide and the mass of the container with the mercury is the mass of oxygen gas lost. Therefore, \begin{align*}73.4gram - 70.2gram = 3.2gram \text{ @ofoxygengas}.\end{align*}

We know the mass of the container with the mercury. To find the mass of the mercury alone, we simply subtract the mass of the empty container. Therefore, \begin{align*}70.2gram - 30.0gram = 40.2gram \text{ @ofmercury}.\end{align*}

This tells us that the ratio of mercury to oxygen is $0.2:0.2$. Now, we can divide the number of mole of each element by the smallest number of mole: \ch{Hg}: \frac{0.2mole}{0.2mole} = 1,\quad \ch{O}:\frac{0.2mole}{0.2mole} =1.
This tells us that the simplest whole number ratio of mercury to oxygen is $1:1$. We can write this as the empirical formula \ch{HgO}.

body.p: In step 1, the mass of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in a sample was divided by the molar mass of the element. In step 2, the number of mole of each element was divided by the smallest number of mole. This gave us a ratio of carbon to hydrogen to oxygen of $1:1.34:1$. In cases like the above, we will need to multiply the ratio by the smallest integer that will produce a ratio with whole numbers.
We can multiply the entire ratio in the example by 3 to give a ratio of carbon to hydrogen to oxygen of $3:4:3$. This gives us an empirical formula of \ch{C3 H4 O3}.

example.title: Determining an Empirical Formula from Percent Composition

stem.p: A vanadium oxide compound is found to be $68\%$ vanadium and $32\%$ oxygen by mass. What is the empirical formula of this compound? Take the atomic masses of vanadium and oxygen to be 51 and 16, respectively.

answer.p: First, we need to assume that the sample size is 100gram. By making this assumption, we know that 68gram of the sample is vanadium and 32gram is oxygen.

This step did not produce a ratio with whole numbers. We will need to multiply the ratio by 2, the smallest integer that will produce a whole number ratio: \ch{V}: 1 \times 2 = 2, \quad \ch{O}: 1.5 \times 2 = 3.
We can write the whole number ratio as a chemical formula, giving us the empirical formula \ch{V2 O3}.

body.p: The chemical formula determined from the percent composition will always be the empirical formula. In order to determine the molecular formula, the molar mass of the molecule must be known. As the molecular formula is a multiple of the empirical formula, the molar mass of the molecule will be a multiple of the molar mass of the empirical formula. Let us examine how to determine the molecular formula from the empirical formula:

Naphthalene is a compound containing carbon and hydrogen that is often used as a moth repellent. The molar mass of naphthalene is 128gram per mole and its empirical formula is \ch{C5 H4}. What is the molecular formula of naphthalene?
We can multiply the subscripts in the empirical formula by this integer to determine the molecular formula: \ch{C5 H4} \times 2 = \ch{C10 H8}.
The molecular formula of naphthalene is \ch{C10 H8}. The process for determining the molecular formula is shown below.

example.title: Determining a Molecular Formula from an Empirical Formula

stem.p: A compound with the empirical formula \ch{C5 H7 NO2} has a molar mass of 339gram per mole. What is the molecular formula of this compound? [\ch{H} = 1gram per mole, \ch{C} = 12gram per mole, \ch{N} = 14gram per mole, \ch{O} = 16gram per mole]

answer.p: In order to determine the molecular formula, we will begin by calculating the molar mass of the empirical formula: \text{@empiricalformulamolarmass} &= \left(5 \times \text{ @molarmassof } \ch{C} \right) + \left(7 \times \text{ @molarmassof } \ch{H} \right) + \left(\text{@molarmassof } \ch{N} \right)\\ & \quad + \left(2 \times \text{ @molarmassof } \ch{O} \right)\\ \text{@empiricalformulamolarmass} &= \left(5 \times 12gram per mole \right) + \left(7 \times 1gram per mole \right) + 14gram per mole + \left(2 \times 16gram per mole \right)\\ &= 113gram per mole.

This value indicates that the molecular formula is three times larger than the empirical formula. We can multiply the subscripts in the empirical formula by the integer to determine the molecular formula: \ch{C5 H7 NO2} \times 3 = \ch{C15 H21 N3 O6}.
The molecular formula of the compound is \ch{C15 H21 N3 O6}.

example.title: Determining the Molecular Formula from the Percent Composition

stem.p: Oxalic acid is an organic compound found in many plants, including rhubarb. It is found to contain $26.7\%$ carbon and $71.1\%$ oxygen, with the rest being hydrogen. If the molar mass of oxalic acid is 90gram per mole, what is its molecular formula? [\ch{H} = 1gram per mole, \ch{C} = 12gram per mole, \ch{O} = 16gram per mole]

answer.p: In order to determine the molecular formula, we need to know the molar mass of oxalic acid (90gram per mole) and the empirical formula. The empirical formula was not provided, but we can determine it from the percent composition data.

First, we will assume that the sample size is 100gram. This means that the sample is composed of 26.7gram of carbon, 71.1gram of oxygen, and 2.2gram of hydrogen. The hydrogen mass was calculated by subtracting the mass of carbon and oxygen from 100gram.
We substitute the ratio as subscripts in a chemical formula, giving us an empirical formula of \ch{CH2 O}.

Now that we know the molar mass of oxalic acid and its empirical formula, we can determine the molecular formula. We begin by calculating the molar mass of the empirical formula: \text{@empiricalformulamolarmass} &= \left(\text{@molarmassof } \ch{C} \right) + \left(2 \times \text{ @molarmassof } \ch{H} \right) + \left(\text{@molarmassof } \ch{O} \right)\\ &= 12gram per mole + \left(2 \times 1gram per mole \right) + 16gram per mole\\ &= 30gram per mole.

This value indicates that the molecular formula of oxalic acid is three times larger than the empirical formula. We can multiply the subscripts in the empirical formula by three to determine the molecular formula: \ch{CH2 O} \times 3 = \ch{C3 H6 O3}.
The molecular formula of oxalic acid is \ch{C3 H6 O3}.

ul.li: A molecular formula indicates the exact number of atom of each element in a molecule.
An empirical formula indicates the simplest whole number ratio of atom of each element in a molecule or ionic compound.
The empirical formula can be determined from the experimental data.
The percent composition by mass can be used to calculate the empirical formula.
The molecular formula can be determined from the empirical formula as long as the molar mass of the molecule is known.
